com.pb.sawdust.calculator

Class NumericFunction2

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.calculator.NumericFunctionN
      • com.pb.sawdust.calculator.NumericFunction2
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Function2<java.lang.Number,java.lang.Number,java.lang.Number>, NumericResultFunction2<java.lang.Number,java.lang.Number>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    NumericFunction2.FlexFunction2

    public abstract class NumericFunction2
extends NumericFunctionN
implements NumericResultFunction2<java.lang.Number,java.lang.Number>
    The NumericFunction2 class is used to specify functions which take two numbers as arguments and return a number. It implements the standard Function2 interface by specifying methods which act on primitives. That is, implementations must be able to deal with any numeric argument (object or primitive). For simplicity, it does not specify apply functions mixing different primitive types; it is assumed that applications will cast to the appropriate types as needed.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  NumericFunction2.DecimalFunction2
      The DecimalFunction2 class provides a FlexFunction2 which acts on decimals.
      static class  NumericFunction2.FlexFunction2
      The FlexFunction1 provides a skeletal implementation of NumericFunction2.
      static class  NumericFunction2.IntegralFunction2
      The IntegralFunction2 class provides a FlexFunction2 which acts on integers.

    • Method Detail

      • mirror

        public static NumericFunction2 mirror(NumericFunction2 function)
        Get a two-argument numeric function which swaps the argument order for a specified two-argument function. That is, if the input function is f(x,y), then the mirrored function would be defined as m(x,y) = f(y,x).
        Parameters:
        function - The input function.
        Returns:
        a function which swaps the argument order for function.

        Apply the function without checking the bounds of the inputs. That is, this function should assume that values exist for values[start] through values[start+getArgumentCount()-1], and that the function should be applied on these values.
